## Key Cost Drivers in Housing Association Projects

::: {style="margin: 48px 0; padding: 32px; background: var(--bim-light-gray); border-radius: 8px;"}
### Typical Refurbishment Programme Breakdown (per unit)

::: {style="display: grid; grid-template-columns: 1fr 1fr; gap: 32px; margin: 24px 0;"}

::: {style=""}
#### Internal Upgrades (40-50%)
- Kitchen replacement: £3,000-5,000/unit
- Bathroom replacement: £2,500-4,000/unit
- Heating system: £2,000-3,500/unit
- Electrical rewiring: £1,500-2,500/unit
- **Subtotal:** £9,000-15,000/unit
:::

::: {style=""}
#### External Works (25-35%)
- External wall insulation: £4,000-7,000/unit
- Window replacement: £2,000-3,500/unit
- Roof works: £1,500-3,000/unit
- External doors: £800-1,200/unit
- **Subtotal:** £8,300-14,700/unit
:::

::: {style=""}
#### Building Services (10-15%)
- Communal heating upgrades: £1,000-2,000/unit
- Electrical distribution: £800-1,500/unit
- Ventilation systems: £500-1,000/unit
- Fire alarm upgrades: £400-800/unit
- **Subtotal:** £2,700-5,300/unit
:::

::: {style=""}
#### Other Costs (10-15%)
- Asbestos surveys/removal: £500-1,200/unit
- Decanting costs: £800-1,500/unit
- Professional fees (8-10%): £1,600-3,000/unit
- Contingency (5-8%): £1,000-2,000/unit
- **Subtotal:** £3,900-7,700/unit
:::

:::

::: {style="text-align: center; margin-top: 32px; padding: 24px; background: var(--bim-charcoal); border-radius: 8px;"}
<h3 style="color: #FFFFFF; margin-top: 0;">Total Typical Range: £23,900-42,700 per unit</h3>
<p style="color: #FFFFFF; font-style: italic;">(Comprehensive Decent Homes refurbishment programme)</p>

<p style="color: #FFFFFF;"><strong>NOTE:</strong> Actual costs vary significantly based on:</p>
<ul style="color: #FFFFFF; text-align: left; display: inline-block;">
<li>Property age and condition</li>
<li>Building type (low-rise vs high-rise)</li>
<li>Occupied vs vacant possession</li>
<li>Scope of works (full vs partial upgrade)</li>
<li>EPC improvement targets (C, B, or A rating)</li>
<li>Local labour and material rates</li>
</ul>
:::
:::

## Our Housing Association Estimation Process

::: {.process-steps}
::: {.process-step}
#### Initial Assessment & Data Review

**Day 1 (4-6 hours)**

**What We Do:**
- Review stock condition surveys
- Examine property types and archetypes
- Study compliance requirements
- Assess grant funding criteria
- Identify resident consultation needs

**Client Provides:**
- Stock condition data
- Property surveys
- Current EPC ratings
- Grant funding requirements
- Resident engagement plans

**Output:** Project scope confirmation
:::

::: {.process-step}
#### Scope Definition & Quantification

**Days 1-4**

**What We Do:**
- Define upgrade specifications
- Quantify per property archetype
- Calculate volume discounts
- Assess phasing requirements
- Map resident impact

**Technology:**
- BIM 5D extraction (if available)
- Property archetype modeling
- Volume quantity analysis

**Output:** Complete quantity take-off (BOQ)
:::

::: {.process-step}
#### Cost Application & Value Engineering

**Days 4-7**

**What We Do:**
- Apply social housing rates
- Identify value engineering options
- Calculate grant funding eligibility
- Include occupied building premiums
- Apply contingencies (5-10%)
- Model alternative scenarios

**Database Sources:**
- BCIS social housing data
- Framework agreement rates
- Recent tender results

**Output:** Detailed cost estimate with options
:::

::: {.process-step}
#### Quality Review & Reporting

**Days 7-9**

**What We Do:**
- Technical peer review
- Check against benchmarks
- Verify grant eligibility
- Prepare resident consultation materials
- Create board presentation
- Schedule meeting

**Deliverables:**
- Executive summary (2-3 pages)
- Cost per unit breakdown
- BOQ with quantities and rates
- Grant funding application pack
- Resident consultation materials

**Format:** PDF + Excel workbooks
:::

::: {.process-step}
#### Presentation & Consultation Support

**Day 9-10**

**What We Do:**
- Present to board/committee
- Explain cost drivers
- Review value engineering options
- Support resident consultation
- Answer member questions
- Provide ongoing advice

**Meeting Options:**
- In-person (UK/Poland)
- Video conference
- Member assembly presentations

**Support:** 30 days post-delivery included
:::
:::

::: {style="text-align: center; margin: 32px 0; padding: 24px; background: var(--bim-light-gray); border-radius: 8px;"}
**Typical Total Duration:** 7-10 working days from data receipt to final report  
**Express Service:** Available for urgent grant deadlines (4-5 days) at 25% premium
:::

## Frequently Asked Questions

::: {.faq-section}
::: {.faq-item}
::: {.faq-question}
**Q: Can you help with grant funding applications?**
:::
::: {.faq-answer}
A: Yes, we regularly prepare detailed cost documentation for grant funding applications including Social Housing Decarbonisation Fund, Affordable Homes Programme, and local authority grants. We provide the cost breakdowns and specifications required by funding bodies.
:::
:::

::: {.faq-item}
::: {.faq-question}
**Q: How do you handle properties with different conditions and sizes?**
:::
::: {.faq-answer}
A: We create property archetypes based on building type, size, and condition, then calculate costs for each archetype. This provides accurate per-unit costs while maintaining detailed breakdowns for the overall programme.
:::
:::

::: {.faq-item}
::: {.faq-question}
**Q: Can you provide materials for resident consultation?**
:::
::: {.faq-answer}
A: Yes, we prepare resident-friendly consultation materials including visual presentations, cost breakdown summaries, alternative option comparisons, and Q&A documentation suitable for member assemblies and individual consultations.
:::
:::

::: {.faq-item}
::: {.faq-question}
**Q: What about estimating for occupied properties?**
:::
::: {.faq-answer}
A: We specialize in occupied building works. Our estimates include phasing strategies, protection measures, decanting costs (where necessary), resident liaison time, and the cost premium for working around occupants (typically 10-15% additional).
:::
:::

::: {.faq-item}
::: {.faq-question}
**Q: How accurate are estimates for Decent Homes compliance?**
:::
::: {.faq-answer}
A: With proper stock condition surveys, we achieve ±5-8% accuracy on Decent Homes refurbishment programmes. We include appropriate contingencies (5-10%) for properties where condition surveys reveal uncertainties.
:::
:::

::: {.faq-item}
::: {.faq-question}
**Q: How do you approach value engineering for tight budgets?**
:::
::: {.faq-answer}
A: We identify value engineering opportunities without compromising quality or compliance. This includes optimizing specifications, exploring alternative materials, value-analyzing phasing options, and maximizing volume discounts through strategic procurement.
:::
:::

::: {.faq-item}
::: {.faq-question}
**Q: What's your fee structure for housing association projects?**
:::
::: {.faq-answer}
A: Fees vary based on programme size and complexity. As a rough guide:
- Small programme (50-100 units): £3,000-6,000
- Medium programme (100-300 units): £6,000-12,000
- Large programme (300-500 units): £12,000-20,000

Express service (4-5 days) carries a 25% premium. Contact us for a specific quote.
:::
:::
